title: Journey and Conquest Instructions
shortSummary: Deuteronomy chapter 2 recounts the Israelites' journey through the wilderness, detailing God's specific commands regarding neighboring nations and territories. It emphasizes obedience to God's guidance, respect for His sovereign allotments, and His promise of victory over enemies like Sihon. This chapter highlights God's faithfulness during the wilderness wanderings and His sovereign control over the conquest of the Promised Land.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - Wilderness Wanderings after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives and conveys God's instructions for the journey and conquest.

keyCharacters.name: Sihon
keyCharacters.description: King of the Amorites whose land God promises to give to Israel; he opposes Israel and is defeated.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Esau
keyCharacters.description: Descendants of Esau dwelling in Mount Seir; God commands Israel not to fight them or take their land.

keyCharacters.name: Moabites
keyCharacters.description: Neighbors of Israel whose land is not to be taken, as it is given to the descendants of Lot.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Ammon
keyCharacters.description: Another neighboring nation whose land is also not to be taken by Israel, as it is allotted to Lot's descendants.

definitions.definition: To go around or encircle, often referring to traveling around a geographical feature.
Land or territory given by God to a people as their inheritance.
A term used by the Ammonites for a race of giants who formerly inhabited their land.
A stream marking a boundary crossed by the Israelites during their wilderness journey.
Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action, often in defiance of God’s will.

outline.heading: Instructions Regarding Esau’s Descendants
outline.description: God commands Israel to pass through the territory of Esau’s descendants without conflict, emphasizing respect for God’s allotment and the need for peaceful trade.

outline.heading: Respect for Moab and Ammon Territories
outline.description: Israel is instructed not to harass or fight the Moabites and Ammonites, as their lands are given by God to Lot’s descendants, with historical notes on previous inhabitants and giants.

outline.heading: Conquest of Sihon and His Land
outline.description: God commands Israel to take possession of the Amorite king Sihon’s land, promising victory and instilling fear among surrounding nations, culminating in Israel’s successful conquest.

application: Trust God’s sovereign plan and timing, even when it requires patience and obedience to His specific instructions.
Respect the boundaries God has set in your life and relationships, avoiding unnecessary conflict and practicing peace.
Rely on God’s promise of provision and victory when facing challenges or opposition.
Remember God’s faithfulness during difficult seasons and let it encourage steadfastness in your spiritual journey.

keyVerses.text: Meddle not with them; for I will not give you of their land, no, not so much as a foot breadth; because I have given mount Seir unto Esau for a possession.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God’s sovereign distribution of land and the importance of respecting His boundaries.

keyVerses.text: This day will I begin to put the dread of thee and the fear of thee upon the nations that are under the whole heaven, who shall hear report of thee, and shall tremble, and be in anguish because of thee.
keyVerses.significance: God promises to establish Israel’s reputation and instill fear in their enemies as a sign of His power and protection.

keyVerses.text: But Sihon king of Heshbon would not let us pass by him: for the LORD thy God hardened his spirit, and made his heart obstinate, that he might deliver him into thy hand, as appeareth this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s sovereign control over human hearts to fulfill His purposes.

keyVerses.text: Only unto the land of the children of Ammon thou camest not, nor unto any place of the river Jabbok, nor unto the cities in the mountains, nor unto whatsoever the LORD our God forbad us.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the importance of obedience to God’s commands, even in matters of conquest and territory.
